Farthest Frontier is a functional, competent, and sufficiently enjoyable game. There's enough to like here, and while some things could've used some extra honing, ultimately there are no glaring issues in play severe enough to push me towards leaving a negative review.

But be that as it may, I found myself irreversibly drifting away upon reaching the third research tier and spending some time with it. Yesterday, I wandered off firmly intending to return the next day in order to press on. Today, I find myself deeply reluctant to continue.

At this point I'm decently convinced that I've seen and experienced enough (if not just about everything), with precious little left to extract from the game. Yes, there's a handful of buildings and production chains I'm yet to build and establish, but sticking around for their sake doesn't feel like a great idea.

[hr][/hr]
See, something's just missing in action when it comes to Farthest Frontier. Would more content help, more buildings/upgrades/technologies/resources/professions/whatnot? Would having more elaborate and tricky mechanics be of use (feels like the game's complexity "budget" was almost entirely snatched by agriculture, leaving little for all the other things)? Probably, yes, but I don't feel this'd be the full solution.

Approaching this from another angle, there isn't much happening within the world of the game, truth be told. Merchants come and go, some villagers occasionally get sick or smacked around by aggressive wildlife, raiders pop up every once in a while, random buildings erupt in flames sometimes. 

There are also blizzards, heat waves, and some crop-related complications (diseases, droughts), and the reason I'm mentioning these separately is, well, because it took me a bit of time to actually remember that they exist. That's how "big" of an impression they've left. So, basically, there are neither windfalls nor curveballs beyond an aforementioned and scarce array of unexciting options.

....alternatively, maybe I've been rewired by Against the Storm, and, moving forward, its cadence is the only one that stands a chance of doing the trick for me. I suppose I can't really exclude this possibility, can I?

[hr][/hr]
Long story short, for me it's plain as day that Farthest Frontier is an honest and solid effort, but in the end it didn't hit the spot. It certainly manages not to miss the mark completely, and for a while I was actually quite pleased with what it had going for it. 

But I was hoping it'd be a longer while, the sort of while that'd end up encompassing several separate playthroughs, not a single unfinished one.

A hesitant thumbs up at best.

A fun city sim in the vein of banished. Large tech/building tree, and nice art for the buildings. If you're looking for something like banished then I think this is a good version of that, although it doesn't have any environmental disasters so the biggest sources of pressure are raiders if you have that turned on and maybe crop diseases on the farms but even then neither of those are truly that troubling.

Speaking of the raids what I did find later on was that no matter how big the raid got I could deal with it every time by just grabbing all my citizens and moving them a short distance from the city centre/vault/foundry etc area. Then waiting for the raiders to surround one of those buildings so that they're focusing on tearing that down and then sending the citizens in to attack them.

No matter the raider they seem to go down pretty quickly when mobbed and even though maybe a dozen citizens might die if I send them in a bit too early that's nothing later on in a map when you have hundreds. Once I figured that out I never felt pressured by a raid and I eventually only started needing to recruit soldiers to deal with the various bandit camps on the map which were way more dangerous as they wouldn't be distracted by your buildings due to living in their own little space.

All of the above is on default settings/map on normal difficulty and I assume the combat/crop disease etc requires a lot more than the occasional glance and a mob of citizens if you play on a harder setting. 

Regardless I don't think the combat is a cornerstone of the game and it's not what I came to the game for so I'm not bothered by it being simple. As I mention at the top I enjoyed my time in the game. I liked trying to build up a functioning city, and trying to unlock the higher levels of the tech tree. However I think I've understood through this that I really prefer the impressions games style of city sim with a campaign, a little story, and maps with focused objectives and this game is definitely not that, but again if you prefer the more open banished style then this is a good modern update on that.

Farthest Frontier is a city-building masterpiece. It came in strong and has only improved since, with a massive amount of potential still ahead. The world feels fluid, realistic and occasionally intimidating in all the right ways. Settlements feel alive, progression is well crafted and thoughtfully paced, and the environment feels tangible. The added tech tree slowed things down compared to early access, which I personally consider an improvement: it gives you more time to refine your town and build the foundation needed to support new development. That realism is a big part of the gameâ€™s charm. Feeling worn down in the mayorâ€™s chair? Wander through the streets and just watch the daily routines. The small details add a surprising amount of joy.

Itâ€™s one of the rare early-access titles I never regretted supporting. It showed potential early on and kept its heart. I can recommend it without hesitation. Itâ€™s easily among the best city builders available. If not the best, period.

Now for the rest of the sandwich.

The Trading Post is a core mechanic, but it becomes too micro-heavy as your town grows. Eventually it starts to feel like a trading-post simulator instead of a city builder. Some smart automation or quality-of-life improvements would help a lot. That said, the required level of control makes sense because one bad trade can genuinely hurt you, and that weight is valuable.

Crafting recipes are sometimes too simplistic. It would feel more cohesive if earlier products fed into later ones (for example, letting hide coats contribute to armor production instead of only raw leather). Still, this isnâ€™t a crafting game, so itâ€™s more of a wish than a flaw.

Combat is where the difficulty spikes. Even on the lowest settings, raids can feel overwhelming. Challenging raiders are fine for realism, but it results in an odd asymmetry: the raid settings matter, yet others (starting resources, wildlife, maladies) barely influence the experience. Wildlife can even be beneficial if you get a convenient endless bucket of hides and meat (aka a cluster of wolf dens). Maladies, meanwhile, donâ€™t do anything because soap is the only real countermeasure. You either have it or you don't. And if they were dangerous, the entire run would hinge on a single Black Death coin flip.

Soldiers being idle most of the time is another rough edge. Adding crime and patrol management would give them purpose and training without just waiting on raids to happen.

None of these points are dealbreakers. Theyâ€™re simply parts of an experience I otherwise consider exceptional. Farthest Frontier remains top tier, and I wholeheartedly recommend it. 9.2/10

One of the better city builders in the last few years. 

It's not perfect, but it does capture something special - a modern Banished vibe. You can make some seriously pretty/interesting colonies in this. It also does present some challenge, for awhile, unlike other city builders that are more like city painters. I like that the game is very slow paced by design.

I do have a few gripes:
- Work areas for hunters and especially foragers create an enormous amount of busywork for anyone that tries to optimize. Foragers especially end up idle during different season unless you manually adjust their work area regularly. Instead, both of these "wander" job types should have an adjustable work radius, including up to unlimited. Fire a warning if they are wandering so far in search of targets that their walking ratio is above X% (e.g. 75%).
- The challenge significantly flattens out around tier 3. By then the basic supply and demand is pretty much wholly met, very stable, and on default settings raids are easily repelled. It feels a bit static at this point. It took me long enough to get there that I didn't feel bad about it - I enjoyed the game greatly to that point. But lack of a challenge made going from tier 3 to 4 feel meaningless. Suggest adding more demands/wants for villagers going to tier 4, maybe some that even create more than just a demand challenge (i.e. upset villagers if you don't fill new needs fast enough). 
- Raid AI is pretty damn stupid. Don't notice it early on when you are very thin on military, but once you have walls etc it becomes painfully obvious just how easy it is to trounce incoming raids of any size with certain wall and tower layouts that don't look like they should be exploits. 
- Better dynamic difficulty would help the above - if I'm simply cruising without any issue, maybe trigger an unusually large weather event, or raid, or domestic unrest event. Even better if they are via systems (not just a random fire event), but anything would be better than the current stasis. 

Still, I really enjoyed my time with this so far. I expect I'll play more in the future - new DLC is pretty much a certain buy for me. I hope they improve some of the points above.

FF is a great medieval city builder with decent resource management and some survival elements in it. 

Some examples of things you'll encounter in the game: You need to make sure your industries are supplying the people with enough food, fuel, clothes, luxuries etc. You need to balance expansion with natural resource abundancy (cut down forest and it will cease to provide deer and forage materials) and your ability to provide food that doesn't spoil. Fail to prep enough firewood and your population will freeze during winter. Then there are the raiders..

You can also adjust the difficulty on all of the above to more hardcore or more cozy.

All in all - great city builder with reasonable depth and a pretty chill attitude.

This is a colony sim where you start with a handful of villagers, and must gather to survive the winter. You will be threatened by wildlife, and soon bandits. The battle system is more akin to Age of Empire RTS than Total War which is fine. You can control individual villagers to prioritize tasks or even fight (though they are squishy and you can't rely on using them forever). Be careful of selecting children for fighting, they can be selected and moved, although it's humorous to imagine; they cannot fight. Obviously your main defense will be soldiers (and towers), you will need to keep them equipped which can be produced by your town or purchased from traders.

The colony sim is like Banished where there is a job menu you can specify how many villagers can be assigned, and building placement is important for local buffs and food retrieval. there is no natural formations so your town will look like a grid which is fine. It has improved what Banished has laid out, as in you can modify/move the work areas for certain gathering buildings (fishing building, herb/hunting buildings) without needing to move the building. Your town center can evolve/upgrade opening more building choices and upgrades (like houses) so you don't really have to spread out as much (in the beginning, you will need to expand later in the run) so you can keep your villagers behind a wall easily.

The difficulty can be adjusted and somewhat customizable; for example you can make the environment/sickness more difficult but have no raiders (pacifist mode)

This is a great game to hold you over when and if Manor Lords releases. I intend to spend many more hours in this game.

There are only a couple of issues with this game. I'll start with the good stuff. The graphics and gameplay (and even music) are great. I find the game rather addictive. It's a great sim game.
On the negative end, the UI is a bit clunky at times, where menus overlap gameplay making stuff a bit difficult. The tutorials don't really get into the details as much as I would like, so I have to go to forums to figure some stuff out. 
There's options for automation, but I haven't found it to be possible. Also, the technology tree is a little clunky too, as you have to confirm your selections, but then you also have to close out the menu. The remifications of the technology you choose isn't really clear or apparent as a newbie--basically, the order of operations matters, but at first, I didn't know what the best order was. 
Money is hard. That's a positive. Money shouldn't be easy. War is also hard. I have wiped out lots of workers due to war. The seasonality makes it so that farmers need to be hunters, and fisherman need to be foragers depending on time of year. I'd love to automate this, but having the control makes it a game worth playing. 
Farming is rather baffling--there are just a lot of options and utilising labour feels difficult for me. Adding too many farmers doesn't seem to maximise things. Also, storage is difficult to discern (the difference between some of them is rather ambiguous). These are all neutral-to-positive comments. This stuff SHOULD be hard, and I like that the difficulties and ambiguities seem... realistic.

Ultimately, the game offers a competent but shallow city-builder experience that gets boring quickly for veterans of the genre.

The thing I was most excited about, which most city builders do not incorporate, is RTS mechanics. Every few years bandits will raid your city and you have to defend it. You have an okay amount of troop options and walls/towers to use. Again, nothing special, but the RTS mechanics also very clearly not the focus of this game. Which is the problem. The difficulty in defending your base isn't actually the invading forces, the difficulty is in micromanaging your troops/villagers. This game has beyond abysmal micro. Getting your archers to stand still and shoot is borderline impossible unless you're willing to individually tell each archer exactly which enemy to shoot and when. Infantry spend most of their time getting stuck on each other. When they're not stuck on each other they're following enemies around instead of attacking. The attack move command doesn't work the way you would expect attack move to work if you've ever played an RTS before. Your archers are going to run into melee range and your infantry are going to run past enemies. Not sure what kind of clown programmed the RTS mechanics into this game but they're beyond infuriating to use. 0/10.

This is one of those games where the first 20 hours or so are very addicting as you learn to swim in an ocean of content and struggle with balancing your economy with logistics and raids; but once you understand how to swim in the ocean, the mechanics all feel really flat and repetitive. Apparently it is a successor to Banished, I never played/heard of that, so to me this game feels very much like Anno.

The good things about this game: the learning curve is rewarding and I think I restarted my game like 15 times before settling on the playthrough where most of my gametime comes in. I think the learning curve for me was easier than it would be for most as I spent lots of hours in Anno and other logistics based building games as well, so for me it was just learning how this game goes about it, but for others this might be a steeper learning curve.

Visually it looks really good on my machine (others state they had performance issues) and seeing the seasons change and snow collect on the ground then melt is a nice touch. Watching the world change form as you build and plan roads is also fun. Mapping your town out and placing your individual buildings to maximize benefits and resources is always a fun little puzzle to solve; the game also makes it very easy to move things around when you realize you may have placed something incorrectly, so design mistakes are not punishing.

My gripe is the flawed logistics systems: most of the storage units don't have dedicated workers to them, and the long distance logistics solution (wagons) don't seem to supply every storage facility. The problem with this is upgrading your residential buildings require that they have a variety of goods, but the citizens/workers are simply too stupid to fill the markets/storage units with the same varieties; rather they stock them with the closest buildings that make those products. This seems like a problem that can be solved 10 different ways easily, and for the life of me I can't get all the storage units/markets to carry everything I'm producing.

The combat in this game is also a chore. The first few times you encounter a raid, it will really set you back as having armed units costs money, and this game honestly provides almost no early game economy other than simply being lucky and finding ruins with gold. The AI in this game is also very sub par; RTS games of the early 90s had much more engaging and intelligent enemy behaviors than this game does. The combat was what I was looking forward to the most in this game as it is presented as a real threat, but I found selecting all my units and telling them to attack units one at a time always had me winning in an open field despite the enemy outnumbering me sometimes like 6:1. It's also just raiders, there aren't any diplomatic options with other nations or castles that you can war with, so the combat feels like something slapped together really quickly.

As many have already stated, the tech tree feels fun at first, but later it feels like a gate more than a boost as all the buildings you need are locked behind technology and if you don't upgrade the right way, technology can be EXTREMELY slow to gain; I had to once wait like 5 in game years for one tech point because I needed a building that was locked behind a technology I didn't research yet and couldn't find a tech point any other way.

Overall the presentation and mechanics had me very captivated and impressed the first 25 hours or so, and then I realized I had mastered them all; at this point I was just playing the game to grow, not for a challenge or purpose, and I didn't find the aesthetics or freedom to build captivating enough to play without some goal to work towards.

I would enjoy being able to recommend this game on it's own merits, but can not.

The game is fundamentally flawed on what makes a city builder engaging for those looking for difficulty/challenge 


Logistically this game is extremely lacking in complexity, even though on the surface it may not appear so.  Villagers are completely incapable of handling distances, despite the existence of wagons.  

There is no simple button of "only allowed wagons to transport" a resource.  Villagers will walk half way across the map to a node, to grab 2 ore, instead of waiting for a wagon to deliver.

You can get gamey with it to try and force it, but to me a city builder has failed on a basic level when you are unable to set such simple limits.

Second, the tech tree suffers from the same problem.  It may appear to offer depth complexity, but that is far from the truth.  Technology mostly exists to speed bump your city and its expansion by locking previous buildings behind tech.

There are glimmers of interesting ideas in the tree, active policies that trade benefirs for penalties; but they are mostly ineffectual or extremely strong to the point where the downside might as well not exist.

I could say more, especially the shallow nature of the military, but overall this game leaves me disappointed.

This game was in early access for over 3 years and whilst they made significant improvements to the game, one of the biggest complaints was the terrain tool. They ignored all feedback and criticism regarding this for over 3 years and released the game to 1.0 with the tool in the same state as it was when they released to early access. Why is the terrain tool such a big issue you may wonder resulting in my negative review and inability to enjoy the game?

Buildings and paths follow the terrain so if you place a building on uneven terrain, it is wonky. This is especially noticeable for the larger buildings. The last time I played the game on a mountain map, my mind broke as I realised my entire Town was completely wonky made worse and more noticeable with the larger buildings and upgrades to housing.

The other issue is that any ranged buildings and units get a bonus to their damage depending on the terrain height relative to their target. This means that to create proper defences, you have this incredibly tedious, unintuitive and somewhat broken tool to try and adjust the terrain heights. It's abysmal and ruins the entire game to the point that most people don't even bother playing on maps that have hills or mountains because they do not want to have to deal with this issue.

I thought these devs would be good because they made Grim Dawn, but I was so wrong. How can you ignore so many complaints about the terrain tool and not do anything to rectify it? It's the worst implementation of a terrain tool I've ever seen in a game in my 3 decades of gaming.

This game has the bones that could be a great town/colony builder but ultimately fails to achieve it's potential due to some glaring issues.

1) The tech tree is very poorly conceived. As an example, there are knowledge nodes you can unlock in Tier 2 of the tree, that you cannot actually construct until you have Tier 3 Town Center or materials from Tier 3 resource buildings. (For example the Market upgrade). There is a major hurdle in obtaining bricks to make any sort of progress towards Tier 3, but you cannot actually make bricks until you are in Tier 3. This means the only real way to progress is to purchase bricks from traders, which from my experience so far, is extremely rare.

2) Fires are extremely overtuned and spread very quickly. Even if you have a well directly next to a building with plenty of water available, 15 villagers will dump buckets on the fire, then walk off to do something else, and now you have to wait for a different set of villagers to continue putting out the fire. By the time they actually are close to putting it out it has now spread to an adjacent building and it just spirals from there. No amount of good placement of wells seems to really help with this.

3) Raiders/Pillagers are extremely also overtuned compared the type of defenses you can obtain in early and midgame. In early/mid game, Towers cost an absurd amount of gold per month compared to the benefit you gain from them. This is especially apparent on higher difficulties where it's essentially impossible to gain victory over raiders without exploiting the enemy AI or cheesing with multiple sets of walls. Raider events also seem to happen every 3 years, on the dot, leaving very little variability in gameplay when you know exactly when raids will happen.

While I do have some hope there could be future patches that address a lot of these issues, the fact they are in version 1.0 (Full release) at all is quite glaring; This game has far less polish on it's core mechanics than I expected from the developers of Grim Dawn.

The variety of gathering, hunting, resource gathering, and buildings you can make in this game is very generous, but it's impossible to fully enjoy these aspects when such glaring issues exist.

This is one of those games where the first 20 hours or so are very addicting as you learn to swim in an ocean of content and struggle with balancing your economy with logistics and raids; but once you understand how to swim in the ocean, the mechanics all feel really flat and repetitive. Apparently it is a successor to Banished, I never played/heard of that, so to me this game feels very much like Anno.

The good things about this game: the learning curve is rewarding and I think I restarted my game like 15 times before settling on the playthrough where most of my gametime comes in. I think the learning curve for me was easier than it would be for most as I spent lots of hours in Anno and other logistics based building games as well, so for me it was just learning how this game goes about it, but for others this might be a steeper learning curve.

Visually it looks really good on my machine (others state they had performance issues) and seeing the seasons change and snow collect on the ground then melt is a nice touch. Watching the world change form as you build and plan roads is also fun. Mapping your town out and placing your individual buildings to maximize benefits and resources is always a fun little puzzle to solve; the game also makes it very easy to move things around when you realize you may have placed something incorrectly, so design mistakes are not punishing.

My gripe is the flawed logistics systems: most of the storage units don't have dedicated workers to them, and the long distance logistics solution (wagons) don't seem to supply every storage facility. The problem with this is upgrading your residential buildings require that they have a variety of goods, but the citizens/workers are simply too stupid to fill the markets/storage units with the same varieties; rather they stock them with the closest buildings that make those products. This seems like a problem that can be solved 10 different ways easily, and for the life of me I can't get all the storage units/markets to carry everything I'm producing.

The combat in this game is also a chore. The first few times you encounter a raid, it will really set you back as having armed units costs money, and this game honestly provides almost no early game economy other than simply being lucky and finding ruins with gold. The AI in this game is also very sub par; RTS games of the early 90s had much more engaging and intelligent enemy behaviors than this game does. The combat was what I was looking forward to the most in this game as it is presented as a real threat, but I found selecting all my units and telling them to attack units one at a time always had me winning in an open field despite the enemy outnumbering me sometimes like 6:1. It's also just raiders, there aren't any diplomatic options with other nations or castles that you can war with, so the combat feels like something slapped together really quickly.

As many have already stated, the tech tree feels fun at first, but later it feels like a gate more than a boost as all the buildings you need are locked behind technology and if you don't upgrade the right way, technology can be EXTREMELY slow to gain; I had to once wait like 5 in game years for one tech point because I needed a building that was locked behind a technology I didn't research yet and couldn't find a tech point any other way.

Overall the presentation and mechanics had me very captivated and impressed the first 25 hours or so, and then I realized I had mastered them all; at this point I was just playing the game to grow, not for a challenge or purpose, and I didn't find the aesthetics or freedom to build captivating enough to play without some goal to work towards.

[h2] Quick explanation: [/h2]
Having played the beta originally, I loved it. The farming system especially, was my favorite out of any in the genre. But after about 20 hours, the 1.0 disappointed me. If you want a quick explanation, it's because the pace of the late game becomes absolutely [b] GLACIAL [/b]. I know this is a given for most strategy and city building games, but the game is designed around several systems that crank it down from "slow" to "borderline reverse".

[h2] Rant explanation: [/h2]
First off, the fun of planning and checking out unlockables wears off after a day or two of playing, and it quickly boils down to a pretty basic tiered progression system, where you have to stock up a bunch of resources before you can upgrade your town center and unlock new buildings. It would be ok if not for the act of stockpiling totally gimping your economy for years, because saving up 150 stone doesn't only require watching as your lethargic pops take 2 months to dig out a single stone block each, but it also means holding off on expanding vital food and luxury industries for several real world hours. This [i]could[/i] in theory be fine, but the game maxes out at [b] ONLY 3x SPEED [/b]. 

If you don't have a nearby deposit for a resource such as stone, I pity you, as the outpost you will need to setup once you find the resource will consume most of your looking time in this game. You will squint your eyes at the screen, trying to figure out if that cobblestone road you paid 50 stone for has increased pop walking speed by 1% or a breakneck 2%. My estimation is somewhere between the two numbers. You will then click the "speed up" button again, and shed another tear as you see that it is indeed stuck at [b] ONLY 3x SPEED [/b]. 

"But andrejb_92, if you need resources, just buy them at the market!" Good idea, mate. I just hope the vendor with the right goods comes along, and that he has enough in stock to upgrade my entire iron industry complex, otherwise i get to spend another hour or two waiting for their ox carts to slowly shamble into my town, because again, [b] ONLY 3x SPEED [/b]. 

Finally, the research system is agonizing. Each research point requires more research than the previous one. Unfortunately, you only get one building for research, which can be upgraded once, and then that's it, you'll eventually be lucky to have one research point per year. Luckily the random knowledge tomes mitigate this somewhat, but it's still a great test for your patience at a warp-cruising [b] 3x SPEED [/b].

Ultimately, if you want a cozy pacifist game, this is really great. If you want a hard-difficulty challenge for some achievement hunting, there's faster and meatier stuff out there.
